titleStmt.title: The Farmer who Was Pregnant with a Foal
titleStmt.author: Hans Sachs

respStmt.name: Mikayla Jordan, Sydney Rester, Edith-Marie Green, and Christopher Hutchinson

respStmt.resp: Encoded in TEI P5 XML by
respStmt.name: Isabel Cai

availability.p: The Global Medieval Sourcebook is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

notesStmt.p: The Farmer who Was Pregnant with a Foal is a comic poem by Hans Sachs (1494–1576), a cobbler and poet from Nuremberg. The work is an example of a Schwank: a genre of short, comic tales about mundane characters and situations, either in prose or verse.

Sachs was one of the most prolific composers of Schwänke and other genres of text designed for public performance in Nuremberg. In all, over 6000 works are attributed to Sachs. He is perhaps best known for his leadership of the Nuremberg Singschule (singing school), a guild-like organization composed of local craftsmen that held gatherings at which members would perform songs that had to fulfil certain criteria of rhyme, meter, melody, and delivery. This tradition of Meistergesang (master song) is perhaps most known to modern audiences from the 1868 Richard Wagner opera Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg (The Mastersingers of Nuremberg), in which Hans Sachs is a leading character.

Other genres Sachs produced include dramatic tragedies and comedies based on Classical and Biblical source material, fables based on the writings of Aesop, religious treatises in support of Martin Luther and the Reformation, and Fastnachtspiele––short, usually comic dramas performed at the beginning of Lent. Hundreds of his works were printed as short pamphlets during Sachs’ lifetime and Sachs also compiled a multi-volume edition of his own collected works before his death.

The Farmer who was Pregnant with a Foal concerns an unnamed farmer who develops a terrible stomachache after over-indulging in wine. He sends his servant to the doctor with a urine sample to inquire about his boss’s ailment (a standard method of diagnosis in sixteenth-century Germany). The servant accidentally spills the farmer’s urine along the way and refills the vial with the urine of the horse he is riding, leading the doctor to declare that the producer of the urine is pregnant with a foal. The simple-minded farmer takes the diagnosis seriously and goes out into the field to give birth to his foal. The poem is in many ways representative of Sachs’s work as a whole: the poem is short, entertaining, bawdy, preoccupied with gender roles and norms, and it pokes fun at the rural inhabitants of the area surrounding Nuremberg; a particular target of urban writers like Sachs.

Hans Sachs dated the work December 9, 1557, although it was not printed until Sachs compiled his collected works in the late 1560s and early 1570s. This work appears in the second volume of his works, first printed in 1570. Two years after writing this Schwank, Sachs turned the work into a Fastnachtspiel. Both works were included in the 26-volume collected works of Sachs edited by Adelbert von Keller and Edmund Goetze between 1870 and 1908.
In our translation, we have tried to maintain the simple and, at times, crude language of Sachs’s text. We have not kept the rhyme scheme of the original work.
Hess, Peter. “Poetry in Germany, 1450-1700.” Early Modern German Literature, 1350–1700, edited by Max Reinhart, Camden House, 2007, pp. 395-465.
A good introduction to poetic forms in sixteenth-century Germany.
Holzberg, Niklas, and Horst Brunner. Hans Sachs: Ein Handbuch. DeGruyter, 2020.
An up-to-date catalog of Sachs’s works, their sources, their reception, and a bibliography.
Benedek, Thomas G. Medicine and Humor from the Writings of Hans Sachs and Hans Folz, Meistersinger. Nova Science, 2018.
A collection of works on medical themes by Hans Sachs, translated into English. Includes the Fastnachtspiel adaptation of “The Farmer who Was Pregnant with a Foal.”

listWit.witness: Der schwanger bawer mit del füll
The Farmer who Was Pregnant with a Foal

projectDesc.p: "The Farmer who Was Pregnant with a Foal" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Ein pawer saß zu Schnepffenrewt,
app.rdg: There was a farmer in Schnepffenreut,

app.lem: Der reit eins tags nach einer brewt.
app.rdg: Who went riding one day after a brew.

app.lem: Het int hitz knollet truncken nein
app.rdg: In the heat he drank a lot of wine,

app.lem: Ein aufigestanden zegen wein.
app.rdg: And racked up an outstanding tab.

app.lem: Des ward im in dem bauch nicht recht.
app.rdg: It didn’t sit right with his stomach.

app.lem: Da schickt er Heintzen, seinen knecht,
app.rdg: So he sent Heintz, his servant,

app.lem: Mit seinem brunnen in die stadt,
app.rdg: Into town with his urine,

app.lem: Bey dem artzet zu suchen rath.
app.rdg: To seek advice from the doctor.

app.lem: Der auff einer merrhen dahin drottet
app.rdg: Heintz trotted there on a mare

app.lem: Und uber ein wiesen hin hottet.
app.rdg: And walked through a field.

app.lem: In dem stach er sein merrhen an,
app.rdg: There he spurred his mare on,

app.lem: Das sie ein weng solt furbas gan.
app.rdg: That she would go a little faster.

app.lem: Da thets ein stolprer auff der straß,
app.rdg: She took a stumble in the road

app.lem: Das er verschüttet das harmglaß.
app.rdg: Which made him spill the urine.

app.lem: Der knecht erschrack ob diesem allen.
app.rdg: The servant was flustered by this.

app.lem: In dem war gleich sein grusel stallen.
app.rdg: But just then, his beast had started urinating.

app.lem: Bald stieg Heintz ab und fieng besunnen
app.rdg: Immediately Heintz dismounted and cleverly caught

app.lem: In sein glaß widerumb ein brannen
app.rdg: A stream in his glass again

app.lem: Und kam mit zu dem artzt hinein.
app.rdg: And he brought it in for the doctor.

app.lem: Als der beschawt den brannen sein,
app.rdg: As he examined Heintz’s sample,

app.lem: Der artzt darob groß wunder het
app.rdg: The doctor marveled greatly

app.lem: Und sich darvor gesegnen thet.
app.rdg: And made the sign of the cross before it.

app.lem: Sprach zu dem knecht: Diese person
app.rdg: He spoke to the servant: “This person,

app.lem: Die ist mit ein füll schwanger gon.
app.rdg: She is pregnant with a foal.”

app.lem: Der pawrenknecht des beimlich lacht.
app.rdg: At this the farmhand laughed to himself.

app.lem: Der artzt im ein purgatzen macht,
app.rdg: The doctor made a laxative for him,

app.lem: Die sol er heim dem krancken bringen,
app.rdg: Which he should bring home to the patient,

app.lem: Dardurch hm wider möcht gelingen.
app.rdg: And which should make him better.

app.lem: Der knecht riet heim, sagt ihm die mehr,
app.rdg: The servant rode home and shared the news with the farmer;

app.lem: Wie eins füllens schwanger wer.
app.rdg: That he was pregnant with a foal.

app.lem: Da der pawer hört diese wort,
app.rdg: When the farmer heard these words,

app.lem: Er rauft sein bar und schrier: Das mordt!
app.rdg: He tore at his hair and screamed bloody murder!

app.lem: Wie sol ich nur das fall gepern?
app.rdg: “How should I give birth to the foal?

app.lem: Sol ich erst ein roßmutter wern?
app.rdg: Am I about to become the mother of a horse?

app.lem: Wern doch all nachtpawrn spotten mein!
app.rdg: All the neighbors will make fun of me!”

app.lem: Sprach zornig zu der frawen sein:
app.rdg: He spoke angrily to his wife:

app.lem: Du hast nur sein wöln herr und mon,
app.rdg: “You’re the only one who has wooly hair and a mane,

app.lem: Da kommet dieses füllein von.
app.rdg: That’s where this little foal comes from.”

app.lem: Und sie mit feusten stieß and schlug
app.rdg: And she pushed and struck him with fists

app.lem: Und bey dem har im hauß umbzug.
app.rdg: And dragged him through the house by his hair.

app.lem: Da er sie nun het wol geschlagen,
app.rdg: When he was about to hit her back,

app.lem: Da thet knecht Heintz erst zu ihm sagen,
app.rdg: Only then Heintz said to him,

app.lem: Er brecht do ein purgatzen kul,
app.rdg: That he had brought back a fresh laxative,

app.lem: Die von im treiben wirdt das füll.
app.rdg: Which would then push the foal out of him.

app.lem: Fro war der pawr, nam die purgatzen.
app.rdg: The farmer was happy and took the laxative.

app.lem: Die würd im bauch in reissn und kratzen.
app.rdg: It tore and scratched in his stomach.

app.lem: Er rieb den bauch und seine lend
app.rdg: He rubbed his stomach and his loins

app.lem: 90 Und meint, es kem sein letztes end.
app.rdg: And thought his final end was coming.

app.lem: Die pewrin thet weinen und schnuppen
app.rdg: The farmer’s wife was crying and sniffling

app.lem: Und macht im ein gelbe käßsuppen,
app.rdg: And made him a yellow cheese soup,

app.lem: Auff das sie ibm leget den grim.
app.rdg: So that she could lessen his anger.

app.lem: Und als sie die nein truge im
app.rdg: And when she brought it in to him

app.lem: Und vergas des milchlöffels sein,
app.rdg: And forgot his ladle,

app.lem: Legt ihm ein kleinen löffel drein,
app.rdg: She laid a small spoon in the soup for him.

app.lem: Geitzig die suppn er schlicken wur.
app.rdg: He was greedily slurping the soup;

app.lem: Den schlickt er nab mit stiel und al.
app.rdg: In the end the spoon went in, too.

app.lem: Est ihm der bauch groß aufigeschwal.
app.rdg: He slurped that down, handle and all.

app.lem: Im hauß lof der pawr umb und wemert.
app.rdg: First his stomach grew big and swollen.

app.lem: Er seufftzet, echtzet unde gemmert.
app.rdg: The farmer ran all through the house and whimpered.

app.lem: In seinem bauch ward im sehr we
app.rdg: He sighed, groaned, and wailed.

app.lem: Und kondt endtlich nicht bleiben me.
app.rdg: His belly began to hurt very badly

app.lem: Loff hinauß und wolt in der kul
app.rdg: Until he could no longer wait.

app.lem: Geperen sein leibhaftig foll.
app.rdg: He ran outside and in the cool wanted

app.lem: Kam auff sein wiessn, den madern klagt,
app.rdg: To bear his incarnate foal.

app.lem: In mit kleglichen worten sagt,
app.rdg: He came to his meadow and complained to the mowers

app.lem: Wie er mit eim füll schwanger was,
app.rdg: That he was pregnant with a foal.

app.lem: Und fiel darnieder in das graß,
app.rdg: And he fell down into the grass

app.lem: Darinn hieß sich umbwalgen er,
app.rdg: And ordered the mowers to roll him around in it,

app.lem: Auff das er dester eh geper.
app.rdg: In order to speed up the birth.

app.lem: So walgeten den pawren thumb
app.rdg: So the mowers rolled

app.lem: Die mäder auff der wiesen umb,
app.rdg: The silly farmer around the meadow,

app.lem: Biß im doch endtlich die purgatz
app.rdg: Until the laxative made

app.lem: Im banch gab manchen harten kratz
app.rdg: His stomach groan loudly

app.lem: Und ibn hart umb das loch wurd nagen.
app.rdg: And began gnawing urgently at his rectum.

app.lem: Da thet er zu seim madern sogen:
app.rdg: Then he said to his mowers:

app.lem: helft mir und lost mich aufsthon!
app.rdg: “Oh help me and let me get up!

app.lem: Ich muß beim eyd mein füllen hon.
app.rdg: I swear I’m having my foal!”

app.lem: Do stund der schwanger pawer auff
app.rdg: Then the pregnant farmer stood up

app.lem: Und schlich nach einer heck hinauff
app.rdg: And waddled up to a hedge

app.lem: Und haucht darnider in den kle
app.rdg: And squatted down in the clover.

app.lem: Und in eim druck und dennoch ee
app.rdg: And in a push and then soon

app.lem: Mit einem lat praschleten scheiß
app.rdg: With a loud resounding shit

app.lem: Die purgatz hinden im außreiß
app.rdg: The laxative escaped from his rear

app.lem: Und sambt dem löffel die purgatzen
app.rdg: And, along with the spoon, the laxative

app.lem: Macht ein groß krachen and laut spratzen.
app.rdg: Created a big blast and loud spluttering.

app.lem: Nun lag in dieser heck ein haß,
app.rdg: Now in this hedge there lay a hare,

app.lem: Welcher darinn entecblaffen was.
app.rdg: Which was sleeping deeply there.

app.lem: Der fuhr auff und lof wunder bald
app.rdg: It woke with a start and ran off very quickly,

app.lem: Mit schönen sprüngen in den wald.
app.rdg: Hopping gracefully into the forest.

app.lem: Der pawr den hasen laufen sach;
app.rdg: The farmer saw the hare running,

app.lem: Vermeint, es wer sein füll, and sprach:
app.rdg: Thought it was his foal and said:

app.lem: Ach kumb her, liebes fülle mein,
app.rdg: “Oh, come here, my beloved foal!

app.lem: Und trinck vor von der mutter dein,
app.rdg: And drink from your mother

app.lem: Die dich yetzunder hat geporn!
app.rdg: Who has just given birth to you!

app.lem: Werst du mir noch so sawer worn,
app.rdg: Even though you have brought me such pain

app.lem: Reut mich doch kein mha noch arbeit,
app.rdg: No effort or work affects me,

app.lem: Schmertz oder angst in dieser zeyt,
app.rdg: Nor pain or fear in this time,

app.lem: Dieweil du yetzt von mir bist worn
app.rdg: 100 Because you have come from me–

app.lem: Ein solche edle frucht geporn.
app.rdg: Born such a noble offspring.

app.lem: Und soltu fort leben auff erdt,
app.rdg: And should you continue to live on earth,

app.lem: Es wirdt auß dir ein weidlich pferdt,
app.rdg: You’ll become a gracious horse

app.lem: Das hinfehrt wie der poltz im wind.
app.rdg: That runs like the arrow in the wind.

app.lem: Du werst mir lieber deno weib und kind.
app.rdg: You will be dearer to me than my wife and children.

app.lem: Ein zweintzig taler gülstu mir gern.
app.rdg: I would gladly give 20 Thaler

app.lem: Het ich dich than daheim gepern,
app.rdg: To have birthed you at home;

app.lem: Zu hanß, so werst mir nicht entioffen.
app.rdg: In the house, so that you wouldn't have escaped.

app.lem: Mich hat gelack und anglück troffen.
app.rdg: I have met fortune and misfortune today.”

app.lem: Gieng heim, legt sich in die sechs wochen
app.rdg: He went home, laid in bed for the six weeks

app.lem: Und hieß ihm gate bißlein kochen,
app.rdg: And had hearty food prepared for him

app.lem: Wie einr andren kindpetterin,
app.rdg: Just like any other new mother.

app.lem: Blieb darnach der lapp wie vorhin.
app.rdg: Afterwards, the idiot was just as before.

app.lem: Der beschluß.
app.rdg: The Conclusion

app.lem: Die fabel and den guten schwanck
app.rdg: The fable and the good prank

app.lem: (Bitt ich) nembt nicht auf in undanek!
app.rdg: I ask you not to be ungrateful for.

app.lem: Es ist gscheben vor langen jaren,
app.rdg: It happened a few years ago

app.lem: Weil die pawn noch einfeltig warn,
app.rdg: When the peasants were still simple;

app.lem: Noch unverschlagen, fromb and schlecht.
app.rdg: Still honest, good, and pious.

app.lem: Da stand es in der welt noch recht.
app.rdg: It stood right in the world then.

app.lem: Das einfalt und frömbkeit auffwachs
app.rdg: The awakening of simpleness and piety

app.lem: In gantzem Teutschland, wünscht Hanns Sachs.
app.rdg: In the whole of Germany, wishes Hans Sachs.
